metadata.titleEn: LA-ICP-MS data of pyrite and chalcopyrite from Jingchong co Cu polymetallic deposit, Hunan Province
metadata.description:
The table includes the data of laser ablation plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) of pyrite and chalcopyrite from Jingchong co Cu polymetallic deposit in Hunan Province. The experimental method was la-icp-ms. The analysis was completed in the National Geological Experiment and testing center. The analytical instrument was Finnigan element 2 ICP-MS with nwr193 nm laser ablation system. In the experiment, helium was used as carrier gas, and the diameter of laser spot was 35 μ m. The pulse frequency is 10 Hz, the laser energy is 80%, the analysis time of each point is 60 s, including 20 s background test and 40 s sample signal. The tested elements include 34S, 57Fe, 59Co, 60Ni, 65Cu, 66zn, 75as, 82se, 96Mo, 107ag, 115In, 118sn, 121Sb, 208Pb, 209bi, etc. The USGS sulfide standards mass1, nist610 and nist612 were used as the combined external standard, kl2g (one of the silicate standard series mpi-ding) as the monitoring standard, and the Fe content analyzed by EPMA as the internal standard.
The above data have been published in EI high-level journals, and the data are true and reliable. The data is stored in Excel.
metadata.instructions: The data were stored in Excel format. "Py" and "CCP" in the excel header represent pyrite and chalcopyrite respectively, and the data point number format is "jc04-1 (Q1)_ 2) , of which 04-1 (Q1_ 2) JC is the place name constant.

literatureList.titleEn: Mineralogical characteristics and mineralization significance of chlorite, pyrite, and chalcopyrite in the Jingchong cobalt-copper polymetallic deposit in Hunan.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method use LA-ICP-MS for analyzing pyrite and chalcopyrite in the Hunan Jingchong cobalt-copper polymetallic deposit?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for analyzing trace elements in pyrite and chalcopyrite in polymetallic deposits?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used for analyzing trace elements in pyrite and chalcopyrite in polymetallic deposits is the Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) technique. This method involves using helium as a carrier gas, with a laser beam diameter of 35 μm, a pulse frequency of 10 Hz, and 80% laser energy. The analysis time for each point is 60 seconds, which includes 20 seconds for background testing and 40 seconds for sample signal. Calibration is achieved using USGS sulfide standards MASS1, NIST610, and NIST612 as external standards, and KL2G as a monitoring standard, with Fe content from electron probe analysis as an internal standard.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used in acquiring trace element data from mineral samples using LA-ICP-MS?
Feature Specification.Answer: Finnigan Element 2 ICP-MS, NWR193 nm laser ablation system, helium carrier gas, 35 μm laser beam diameter, 10 Hz pulse frequency, 80% laser energy, 60 seconds analysis duration, 20 seconds background testing, 40 seconds sample signal acquisition, elements tested: 34S, 57Fe, 59Co, 60Ni, 65Cu, 66Zn, 75As, 82Se, 96Mo, 107Ag, 115In, 118Sn, 121Sb, 208Pb, 209Bi, USGS sulfide standard MASS1, NIST610, NIST612, KL2G monitoring standard, Fe content from electron probe analysis as internal standard

Quantification.Question: How many elements are analyzed in a dataset using the LA-ICP-MS method for 湖南井冲钴铜多金属矿床?

Definition.Question: What does 'LA-ICP-MS' mean in the context of data collection methods for mineral analysis?
Definition.Answer: LA-ICP-MS stands for Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry, a data collection method used for analyzing the composition of minerals like pyrite and chalcopyrite by ablating a sample with a laser and measuring the ions generated using a mass spectrometer.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to employ LA-ICP-MS techniques for analyzing pyrite and chalcopyrite in polymetallic deposits?
Goal Orientation.Answer: LA-ICP-MS techniques provide detailed elemental analysis necessary for geochemical modeling, supporting the understanding of complex mineral compositions within polymetallic deposits.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing LA-ICP-MS data specifically for pyrite and chalcopyrite in polymetallic deposits?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves using LA-ICP-MS (Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry) with a Finnigan Element 2 ICP-MS equipped with a NWR193 nm laser ablation system. Helium is used as the carrier gas, with a laser spot diameter of 35 μm, pulse frequency of 10 Hz, and 80% laser energy. Each analysis point is measured for 60 seconds, with 20 seconds for background testing and 40 seconds for sample signal. Elements tested include 34S, 57Fe, 59Co, 60Ni, 65Cu, 66Zn, 75As, 82Se, 96Mo, 107Ag, 115In, 118Sn, 121Sb, 208Pb, and 209Bi. Calibration involves using USGS sulfide standards MASS1, NIST610, and NIST612 as external standards and KL2G as a monitoring standard, with Fe content measured by electron probe analysis as the internal standard.

Enablement.Question: What specific instrumentation and methodological advancements enable the precise collection of trace element data in polymetallic mineral deposits?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a Finnigan Element 2 ICP-MS plasma mass spectrometer equipped with an NWR193 nm laser ablation system enables precise collection of trace element data. The methodology involves using helium as a carrier gas, a laser spot size of 35 μm, a pulse frequency of 10 Hz, and 80% laser energy, with an analysis time of 60 seconds per point, including 20 seconds for background testing and 40 seconds for sample signal.
